Co3O4 supported on bone-derived hydroxyapatite as potential catalysts for N2O catalytic decomposition Xuhui Wei Conceptualization Methodology Investigation Writing - original draft a b Yongzhao Wang Conceptualization Writing - review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition a * Xiao Li Conceptualization Validation a b Ruifang Wu Resources Data curation a Yongxiang Zhao Project administration Funding acquisition a a Engineering Research Center of Ministry of Education for Fine Chemicals, Shanxi University, Taiyuan, 030006, China Engineering Research Center of Ministry of Education for Fine Chemicals Shanxi University Taiyuan 030006 China Engineering Research Center of Ministry of Education for Fine Chemicals, Shanxi University, Taiyuan, 030006, China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanxi University, Taiyuan, 030006, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shanxi University Taiyuan 030006 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanxi University, Taiyuan, 030006, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Natural hydroxyapatite (nHAP) obtained from roasted pork bone was used as carrier of Co3O4 to prepare Co/nHAP catalyst for N2O catalytic decomposition. For the sake of contrast, the catalytic activity of Co3O4 supported on synthetic HAP (Co/HAP-Syn) and pure Co3O4 were also investigated. Activity tests indicate that the Co/nHAP could achieve higher catalytic activity than Co/HAP-Syn and pure Co3O4, even in impurity gases, as well as superior stability. The characterization results concluded that, compared with those on Co/HAP-Syn, the sizes of Co3O4 particles on Co/nHAP are smaller, which may contribute to enhance the quantity of active sites. More importantly, the existence of K, Na and Mg elements on the nHAP derived from bone can weaken the CoO bond and increase the amount of oxygen vacancies. All these factors could promote the catalytic activity as well as less inhibition affected by impurity gases. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on N2O catalytic decomposition making use of abandoned bones as effective support material, which can develop a sustainable and promising solution to the growing problem of environment. Keywords Bone-Derived hydroxyapatite N2O catalytic decomposition CoO bond Oxygen vacancies 1 Introduction Currently, nitrous oxide (N2O) has become the largest ozone-depleting substance in the atmosphere, which can weaken the barrier against ultraviolet radiation, thereby affecting human health [1]. In the meantime, it is the third most potent greenhouse gas, with global warming potential (GWP) 310 times higher than that of CO2 [2]. Among the anthropogenic emissions, nitric and adipic acid production as well as automobile exhaust with the emission levels of 0.9 million ton per year belongs to the most important one [3]. Consequently, there is an urgent need to develop effective technologies to reduce the N2O content in the atmosphere. The direct catalytic decomposition of N2O is one of the most promising remediation technologies for N2O emissions abatement. And various types of catalysts including noble metals [4–6], metal oxides [7–9], and ion-exchanged zeolites [1,2,10] have been studied. Noble metal (Ru, Rh) are considered to the most efficient catalysts for N2O catalytic decomposition, however their large-scale applications are limited due to their accompanied affordability and deficiency of storage capacity. Recently, a considerable literature has grown up around the theme of non-noble metal oxides, especially Co3O4, which has been recognized to the potential candidate owing to the defined structure, facile preparation and economically favorable price [11–13]. Furthermore, a number of attempts have been made to improve the catalytic performance of single cobalt spinel by adding the second component (such as alkali, alkaline-earth, transition as well as rare earth metals) to changing the texture, electronics, bond energy and acid-base properties [14–18]. Nevertheless, since the N2O catalytic decomposition is a gas-solid two-phase reaction, a large amount of the bulk phase active component cannot be fully utilized, leading to the low atom efficiency. This problem can be solved by supporting the active cobalt spinel phase on an appropriate support. It has been fully proved that the carrier has the function of dispersing the active phase and plays an important role in stability of the active species, as well as reducing the cost [1,7,8]. As a carrier with porosity, bio-compatibility, defined structure and adjustable acidity and alkalinity, hydroxyapatite [HAP, Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2], has been used as carriers to prepare catalysts for ethanol reforming [19], formaldehyde combustion [20], and hydrogen generation [21]. Especially, the high mechanical strength and thermal stability (more than 1000 ℃) make it have a satisfactory prospect in industrial application. However, there are some apparent disadvantage for the synthesized HAP supports, high-cost, non-environmentally friendly and complicated preparation process. Consequently, it is urgent to find a kind of support with low price, environmental protection and facile preparation method. Nature demonstrates a diverse species through evolution, affording us important inspiration for materials design and synthesis. It is known that the hydroxyapatite (HAP) support could be prepared via waste materials such as incrustation scale, shell and bones. It can conceivable that using waste as the source of catalyst not only provides an economic and environmental protection strategy, but also helps to utilize waste materials properly. Recently, efficient catalysis utilizing waste bones for water-gas shift [22], oxidation of 2, 6-diisopropylnaphthalene [23] and oxygen reduction [24] has been achieved, and a sustainable material cycling toward green catalysis has been created. However, few researchers have been able to draw on any systematic study into the utilization of waste bone to synthesize catalyst for N2O catalytic decomposition. Here, we adopt a simple one-step method for the preparation of natural hydroxyapatite (nHAP) from pork bone waste, and then nHAP was used as an effective carrier. The Co3O4 supported on nHAP were utilized for the N2O catalytic decomposition, and Co3O4 loaded on synthetic HAP (Co/HAP-Syn) and pure Co3O4 were also prepared as comparison. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, TEM, HADDF-STEM, N2-physisorption, ICP, FT-IR, H2-TPR, XPS and O2-TPD techniques. In view of the characterization results, the relationship between the structure and the catalytic performance has been expounded. 2 Experimental Catalyst preparation, characterization and tests procedure are shown in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Element analysis To determine the elemental composition of the Co/nHAP, Co/HAP-Syn and their supports, Co, Ca, P, K, Na and Mg contents of the samples were assayed by ICP-AES (Table 1 ). As observed from the second column of Table 1, the actual Co contents of Co/nHAP and Co/HAP-Syn are 15.10 wt.% and 15.05 wt.%, respectively. It is worthy of note that the nHAP and Co/nHAP samples contain relatively high concentrations of alkali and alkaline-earth metals species-K (∼0.46 wt.%), Na (∼1.03 wt.%) and Mg (∼0.73 wt.%), compared to the HAP-Syn and Co/HAP-Syn (∼0.02 wt.% K, 0.03 wt.% Na and 0.01 wt.% Mg), as reported previously [22,23]. Furthermore, as displayed in the Figure S1, the XPS survey spectra also reveal the existence of peaks for K2p, Na1s and Mg1s on the Co/nHAP surface, whereas it is not obvious for the Co/HAP-Syn, which is in accord with the ICP result. In addition, the Ca/P molar ratios (Table 1) of the nHAP and Co/nHAP are 1.46 and 1.47, lower than that of the theoretical stoichiometric HAP (1.67), which confirm the non-stoichiometry of nature HAP support, and it is the same as reported literature [22,23,25]. The main reason may be that the existence of alkali and alkaline-earth metals (K, Na and Mg) partially replaced the Ca in HAP [25]. 3.2 Structure and texture property of samples The XRD analysis are conducted and shown in Fig. 1 . Note that both the diffraction peaks of the natural and the synthetic supports are well indexed to the standard hydroxyapatite phase (JCPDS#09−0432). This reveals that HAP carriers have been successfully prepared by the calcination of bones and precipitation synthesis in the text, and there is no other phase formation. After loading appropriate Co3O4 on the nHAP and HAP-Syn supports, the XRD patterns contain additional diffraction peak other than those coming from hydroxyapatite phase. The peak appearing at 2θ = 37° is assigned to Co3O4 that crystallizes in the spinel structure (JCPDS#42−1467), which is coincided with TEM (Fig. 3) and FT-IR (Fig. 5) results. Clearly, the formation of Co3O4 leads to lower intensity and broader peak of both main HAP diffraction feature at 2θ = 25.9, 31.7° and 32.9°, which means decreased crystallinity and grain sizes, and it is very likely that there is a strong interaction between Co3O4 and HAP [26]. Additionally, the diffraction peaks of the Co3O4 are broadened for the Co/nHAP in comparison to that for Co/HAP-Syn, which indicate that Co3O4 nanoparticles are smaller on the nHAP surface. Accordingly, the average grain sizes of Co3O4 for two samples are estimated on the basis of Scherrer equation, which are 24.2 and 13.5 nm for Co/HAP-Syn and Co/nHAP (Table 2 ), respectively. N2 adsorption-desorption experiment was conducted to inspect the textural properties for prepared materials. As presented in Fig. 2 , on the basis of IUPAC classification, all samples possess typical type IV curves and H3 hysteresis loops. When the relative pressure is higher than 0.9 of P/P0, the sharp change of nitrogen adsorption volume can be observed, which is due to the large number of macropores formed by the accumulation of particles [27]. The pore size distributions (illustration in Fig. 2) on the bone derived hydroxyapatite materials appear to show a bi-modal distribution characteristic, and its peaks are mainly concentrated at 23 nm and 41 nm. Meanwhile, synthetic samples also show similar pore size distributions, and only the intensity of the peak at 23 nm was slightly lower than that of Co/nHAP. The textural properties, including the specific surface area (SBET), pore volume (Vp), and average pore diameter (dp) for the studied samples are gathered in Table 2. It is shown that the HAP-Syn and Co/HAP-Syn possess the slightly higher SBET (36 and 29 m2/g) in comparison with the nHAP and Co/nHAP (33 and 25 m2/g). Besides, the Vp and dp of the natural samples were lower than those of the synthetic samples. However, the little changes between catalysts with different support were inconsiderable. On the other hand, it is worth mentioning that the adding of Co3O4 has caused the decrease of specific surface area and pore volume, which can be ascribed to the Co3O4 particles filling the partial pores [11]. To further investigate the surface morphologies and crystalline structures of the prepared samples, (HR)-TEM analysis (Fig. 3) was performed to gain more information. As can be seen, the morphology of the HAP-Syn support shows a rod structure (Fig. 3a), differently, sheet-like structure (Fig. 3b) attributed to nHAP is observed. Then, the particle size of the supports has been estimated and listed in Table 2. Specifically, the support grain size (68−76 nm) of Co/HAP-Syn observed by TEM does not coincide with the aforementioned XRD results (43 nm) (Table 2), which may be due to the observed rod-like structure with uneven length and width, while the XRD testing the average particle size of the samples. As displayed in Fig. 3d, there are some small Co3O4 particles on the Co/nHAP, however, a few aggregated Co3O4 particles are also observed, so the particle size distribution in TEM image is not clear. In addition, highly condensed Co3O4 particles are observed when the Co3O4 was loaded on the HAP-Syn support (Fig. 3c). That is, the nHAP results in the formation of Co3O4 particles with less aggregation compared with Co/HAP-Syn, which may be caused by the stronger interaction between Co3O4 and nHAP. HR-TEM images of Fig. 3e and f show a well-defined lattice fringe with d-space value of 0.8 nm and 0.46 nm, belonging to the (100) face of HAP and (111) face of spinel Co3O4, respectively. HAADF-STEM and EDX elemental mapping images observed in Fig. 4 and Figure S2 provide the morphological features and an overview of the dispersion of the Ca, P, O, Co, K, Na and Mg elements on the supports for Co/nHAP and Co/HAP-Syn, respectively. The map of Co/nHAP (Fig. 4) reveals that the distribution and shape of Ca, P, O, K, Na and Mg element signals are basically similar to HAADF-STEM images, indicating that these elements are evenly dispersed in the Co/nHAP. It is worth noting that Co is not as uniformly dispersed as Ca, O and other elements, and a more poor dispersion was also observed on HAP-Syn samples (Figure S2). Overall, Co is relatively more dispersive on nHAP than Co/HAP-Syn. In addition, as expected, Co/nHAP sample contains more and clearer distributions of K, Na and Mg element, which may provide the possibility of interaction with Co3O4. All the results obtained keep the same with ICP, XRD and (HR)-TEM results above. FT-IR spectroscopy (Fig. 5) was conducted to detecting the information of chemical bonds or characteristic groups for all samples. It is seen in Fig. 5 that both nature and synthetic samples show the typical phosphate absorption bands, attributed to the PO ʋ1 (961 cm−1), ʋ2 (471 cm−1), ʋ3 (1093 and 1037 cm−1) and ʋ4 (601 and 566 cm−1) vibrational bands [21]. Moreover, the vibrations of OH groups existed in the apatite framework are evidenced by observation of the band at 3575 and 630 cm-1. In addition, the extra bands at 3350–3550 and 1642 cm−1 are found, which can ascribe to the stretching as well as bending modes of absorbed water [21]. Specifically, the spectra of nHAP and Co/nHAP exhibit a band of 874 cm-1, which can be ascribed to hydrogenphosphate groups (HPO4)2-, but it is not obvious in the spectra of the synthesized Co/HAP samples. In general, a stoichiometric HAP (Ca/P = 1.67) material has the formula of Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2. A non-stoichiometric HAP sample has a formula of Ca10−x(HPO4)x(PO4)6−x(OH)2−x (0 < x < 1), i.e., Ca/P ratio is below 1.67. So, the nature samples with presence of (HPO4)2- and lower Ca/P ratio are typical of calcium deficient hydroxyapatite, which is due to the existence of alkali and alkaline-earth metals only in the nature samples [22,25]. It is worth noting that the spectra of Co/nHAP and Co/HAP-Syn did not change significantly compared to their support. However, both catalysts display a new band at 663 cm−1 which can be ascribed to the CoO stretching vibration characteristic of spinel Co3O4 based on XRD results. In general, the FT-IR spectrum of spinel Co3O4 possesses two characteristic bands of Co3+-O and Co2+-O, at around 665 and 580 cm−1, respectively. Here, the characteristic band of Co2+-O is not observed, which may be covered by the band of OPO bending mode (602 cm−1) of HAP. Moreover, after the carrier was impregnated with Co(NO3)2, the strength of band attributed to the nitrate band (1384 cm−1) became stronger, indicating that there was residual nitrate after calcination. 3.3 Redox and surface properties of samples Fig. 6 shows the H2-TPR profiles of all samples. For HAP supports, the peak (ε) in the range of 600–740 ℃ is attributed to the dehydroxylation process of the support [28,29]. With regard to the both catalysts, the peaks observed at low temperatures (α) belong to the reduction of surface oxygen species [30]. Furthermore, there are two obvious H2 consumption peaks for both catalysts at 260–440 ℃ (β), corresponding to the reduction of Co3O4 particles at the external surface of the HAP. Generally, the reduction of Co3O4 is described to occur in successive steps, with the following steps identified: 1) the reduction of Co3+ ions to Co2+ (β1) and 2) the reduction of Co2+ ions to Co° (β2) [31]. An additional reduction peak at 450–550 ℃ emerges in the cases of two catalysts, which is ascribed to the reduction of CoOx clusters strongly interacting with the support. It is worth to note that the peak area of each catalyst above 600 ℃ is greater than the dehydroxylation peak area of its corresponding support, indicating that the catalyst has a reduction of additional Co species apart from the dehydroxylation process of the support in this temperature range. The Co species is generally assigned to the reduction of Co2+ at ion exchange sites (Ex Co2+), indicating that the ion exchange process will inevitably occur during the impregnation process, which is in accord with previous reports [19–21]. The reduction peak positions (Tmax) and H2 consumption values of Co/HAP samples are listed in Table S2. On the Co/nHAP profile the Tmax of the β1 and β2 peaks shift toward lower temperatures compared with those of Co/HAP-Syn catalyst, which manifests the stronger interaction between Co3O4 and nHAP. For example, the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ (β1) primarily centred at 289 ℃ on the Co/nHAP, which is 56 ℃ lower than that over Co/HAP-Syn (Table S2). These results demonstrate that Co3O4 loading on nHAP supports markedly facilitates the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+, indicating the weakened CoO bond, which may be caused by the presence of K, Na and Mg elements on the nHAP. Interestingly, similar results are also found on the H2-TPR profile of K-doped Co3O4, which demonstrates that the oxygen anion can lose the electron flow to the K+ cation and then weaken the Co-O bond [12,13]. For further explanation, as we all know, alkali and alkaline-earth cations are Lewis acids, which have no electron donation effects [32]. However, oxygen anions in the coordination sphere of the cations are highly basic and therefore electron donation from highly basic oxygen anions toward K+, Na+ and Mg2+ ions decreases the electronic cloud density of oxygen anions, which weakens the CoO bond. Accordingly, XPS spectra of O1 s (Fig. 7 b) confirm that the electronic density of oxygen have decreased via the result showing that the O1 s peak of Co/nHAP shifts to the higher BE compared with that of Co/HAP-Syn. In order to illuminate the chemical environment as well as electronic state of the elements existing in prepared samples, XPS studies of Co and O atoms have been carried out. As the Fig. 7a shows, the Co2p3/2 signals for both catalysts, centered at around 781.2 and 779.5 eV, can be fitted with Co2+ (α) and Co3+ (β), respectively. The satellite peak (γ) is also observed at about 788.6 eV, indicating the presence of Co2+. Here, what merits our attention is that, the Co 2p3/2 peak position of the Co/nHAP shifts to lower BE (779.2 eV vs. 779.7 eV) compared to that of the Co/HAP-Syn catalyst. It indicates that the CoO bond binding energy decreases about 0.5 eV, supporting the conclusion (H2-TPR) that K, Na and Mg can weaken the Co–O bond. This result is quite close to the reported K/Na/Mg-doped Co3O4 involving Co 2p3/2 [15,33,18], where the binding energy reduces about 0.5 eV compared to that of Co3O4. Hence, it can be concluded that K, Na and Mg in the nHAP have the important function of weakening the CoO bond, just like K showing the same effect on Co3O4 [15]. Simultaneously, the ratio of Co3+/Co2+ is calculated on the basis of the fitting results and listed in Table S3. It can be seen that the value of Co3+/Co2+ is about 1.05 on the surface of the Co/HAP-Syn catalyst, whereas which is about 1.35 for Co/nHAP. It indicates that the amount of surface Co3+ increase over the Co/nHAP compared with that over Co/HAP-Syn. On the exposed surface of the spinel structure (AB2O4), the octahedral trivalent B ion is easy to lose some oxygen atoms and form a coordination unsaturated state, and then oxygen vacancy is produced on the surface. For instance, Russo and his co-authors [34] studied a series of spinels with divalent metal ion (Cr2+, Ca2+, Fe2+ etc.) as the A cation, and Co3+, Fe3+ or Cr3+ as the B cation. It was found that the amount of oxygen vacancies over spinel surface is mainly decided by the B sites, while it is almost unaffected by the A sites. In brief, oxygen vacancies are strongly dependent on the amount of Co3+, and more Co3+ means the possibility of a larger number of oxygen vacancies, which is corroborated by O 1s XPS and O2-TPD results. Moreover, the O 1s spectra of Co/nHAP and Co/HAP-Syn catalysts in Fig. 7b could be divided to three species, which include surface lattice oxygen species (Oα1, 530.7 eV), the surface oxygen species adsorbed on the oxygen vacancy (Oα2, 531.7 eV) and OH− or H2O species (Oα3, 533.0 eV) [35–37]. Furthermore, the surface atomic ratio of (Oα2) to (Oα1+Oα2+Oα3) was calculated for the two catalysts and listed in Table S3. The Oα2/(Oα1+Oα2+Oα3) of Co/nHAP (0.36) is higher than that of Co/HAP-Syn (0.28), indicating that Co/nHAP possesses more amount of surface oxygen vacancy. In the reported literatures [27,30], O2-TPD characterization technology can well detect the generation and quantity of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. As depicted in Fig. 8 , there are two peaks from 100 °C to 600 °C over the Co/nHAP and Co/nHAP catalysts. Generally, the peak ranging from 100−350 °C and >400 °C can be ascribed to the desorption of surface oxygen species on the oxygen vacancy, as well as lattice oxygen species, respectively [32]. Clearly, Co/nHAP gives much larger O2 desorption area belonging to the surface adsorbed oxygen species (100−350 °C) compared with Co/HAP-Syn. Accordingly, the amounts of surface adsorbed oxygen species over Co/nHAP and Co/HAP-Syn are 15.6 and 5.2 μmol g−1, respectively. Consequently, the Co/nHAP catalyst processes more amount of oxygen vacancies, which is identical to the XPS results. In addition, compared with Co/HAP-Syn, the desorption peak of the surface oxygen species for Co/nHAP shifts to the lower temperature. Thus, it can demonstrate that the desorption of surface oxygen species is easier on Co/nHAP, which is owing to the weakened CoO bond. 3.4 N2O catalytic decomposition activity As shown in Figure S3, the nHAP and HAP-Syn supports have little catalytic activity in the temperature range of 200–600 ℃. The catalytic activities of prepared catalysts for N2O decomposition are showed in Fig. 9 . It is obvious that the N2O decomposition activity for Co/nHAP catalyst is superior to that of Co/HAP-Syn. For instance, the N2O conversion of Co/nHAP starts at about 300 ℃, while for the Co/HAP-Syn it reaches about 340 ℃. Moreover the temperature of complete N2O conversion reaches at about 460 ℃ for Co/nHAP, however that is about 540 ℃ for Co/HAP-Syn. Generally, O2, H2O, NO and CO2 are the common constituents in the industrial tail gas. Fig. 9 a and b also show the results of N2O catalytic decomposition in the feed gas of 0.1 vol.% N2O/Ar with 3.0 vol.% O2, 4.4 vol.% H2O, 0.015 vol.% NO or 4.0 vol.% CO2. It is clearly seen that the addition of O2, H2O, NO or CO2 impurity gas all inhibit the catalytic activity to varying degrees. Previous studies have shown that O2, H2O, CO2 as well as NO play the distinct roles in inhibition mechanisms for N2O decomposition [38]. H2O or CO2 would be apt to combine with oxygen vacancy to occupy the active site, and then prevent the adsorption of N2O, while NO is easy to consume unstable oxygen to produce competitive oxidation effect to generate NO2, then reduce the regeneration of active site [39]. Furthermore, oxygen usually can move the balance of Equation (O* + O* → O2* → O2 + *) to the left, thus inhibiting the desorption of O* as well as the regeneration of active site. On the other hand, there is also a possible competitive adsorption between O2 and N2O, like H2O or CO2. What's interesting is that, the catalytic activities are evidently inhibited by addition of H2O or O2 (Fig. 9 a) for Co/HAP-Syn catalysts, while it is not obvious for Co/nHAP. For example, for Co/HAP-Syn, the N2O conversion curve shifts toward higher temperature around 42 °C at 50 % N2O conversion due to the presence of H2O, while that is only about 15 °C for Co/nHAP. Therefore, although both catalytic activities are inhibited by H2O, Co/nHAP catalyst is of relatively high tolerance to H2O, which can be ascribed to the weakened Co–O bond abating the adsorption of H2O. Accordingly, due to the strong Co–O bond strength of Co/HAP-Syn, its catalytic performance is seriously inhibited by H2O. Furthermore, compared Co/HAP-Syn, Co/nHAP also exhibits superior catalytic activity in the presence of O2, CO2 and NO (Fig. 9). Additionally, the catalytic stability has been examined for the Co/nHAP in the conditions: 1000 ppm N2O/Ar with 4.4 vol.% H2O, 3.0 vol.% O2, 3.0 vol.% O2+4.4 vol.% H2O, 0.015 vol.% NO or 4.0 vol.% CO2. As the Fig. 10 shows, because of the addition of 4.4 vol.% H2O, under the condition of 460 °C, the N2O conversion rate of the Co/nHAP has just decreased from complete conversion to 96 %, so a certain amount of H2O in the feed gas has a small effect on the catalytic activity. The further introduction of 3.0 vol.% O2 into the feed gas makes the N2O conversion decrease to 88 %, indicating the inhibitory effect of O2 is more prominent than that of H2O. Similar lightly decrease in catalytic activity can also be observed when NO or CO2 was injected into the feed gas in 1000 ppm N2O/Ar. Finally, after the impurity gases were removed from the feed stream, the catalytic activity for Co/nHAP recovers to 100 %. It demonstrates that the reason for the decrease of N2O catalytic decomposition activity is the competitive adsorption of impurities (such as H2O, O2, NO as well as CO2) on the active site with N2O, namely, that is dynamic factor [38]. Hence, the Co/nHAP catalyst was compared with the pure Co3O4 for the catalytic activity to elucidate the preponderance of nature HAP support. As shown in Figure S4, the T90 in the presence of 4.4 vol.% H2O over pure Co3O4 is 525 °C, while it is 440 ℃ over Co/nHAP under the same reaction conditions. Evidently, Co/nHAP exhibits more excellent catalytic performance in the presence of 4.4 vol.% H2O, compared with pure Co3O4 catalyst. For further comparison, some supported noble metals, transition metals, and zeolite catalysts reported in the literatures have been summarized in Table 3 . It can be shown that the catalytic activity and the tolerance to the common impurity gas of Co/nHAP have reached the same level. A case in point is that Ni/CeO2 catalyst shows relatively high catalytic performance, but it is known that the price of rare earth element Ce is exorbitant, so using it as a carrier will undoubtedly increase the cost. Therefore, economic-competitive Co3O4/nHAP catalysts show great potential for N2O catalytic decomposition. On the one hand, compared with noble metal catalysts or metal oxide catalysts (such as pure Co3O4), Co3O4/nHAP not only exhibits high catalytic activity but also has high utilization of active components. On the other hand, more importantly, compared with Co3O4/synthetic supports, bone-derived HAP support is more cost-effective and environment friendly than synthetic supports, because it is made from discarded bones. In addition, we also investigated the common transition metals supported on nHAP (Figure S5) and found that the order of catalytic activity follows the following: Co/nHAP>Ni/nHAP>Cu/nHAP>Fe/nHAP. 3.5 Kinetics of the reaction over Co/nHAP, Co/HAP-Syn and Co3O4 The N2O catalytic decomposition on Co3O4-based catalysts is considered as a first order reaction [48]. Table 4 lists the specific reaction rate (r) and the corresponding rate constant (k) obtained from the kinetic study of Co/nHAP, Co/HAP-Syn and Co3O4 catalysts. The Co/nHAP catalyst gives about 3.0 and 11.1 times larger specific reaction rate as those of pure Co3O4 and Co/HAP-Syn, respectively. For example, at 380 °C, the r on Co/nHAP is 0.0377 μmols−1 g−1 whereas that on pure Co3O4 is only 0.0125 μmols−1 g−1. In the light of the k under different temperatures, the activation energy (Ea) has been obtained according to the Arrhenius equation (Ln k = ln A ‒ Ea/RT). As shown in Figure S6, the Ea on three catalysts show the follow sequence : Co/nHAP (103.49 kJ mol-1)＜pure Co3O4 (117.94 kJ mol-1)＜Co/HAP-Syn (157.50 kJ mol-1). Definitely, the remarkable reduction of Ea of the reaction over Co/nHAP than that over pure Co3O4 and Co/HAP-Syn can be also attributed to the function of K, Na, and Mg existing in the nature HAP, which can weaken the CoO bond and increase the amount of oxygen vacancies. The XRD results show that both the catalysts are composed of HAP and Co3O4 phase, ruling out the formation of any the third one. However, the crystallinity decreases and the crystallite size becomes smaller for the Co3O4 particles on the nHAP support than that on HAP-Syn. It is reasonable to deduct that the smaller Co3O4 particles may contribute to enhance the quantity of active sites and thus promote the N2O catalytic decomposition activity. Furthermore, there are more K, Na and Mg elements (ICP and XPS) in nature samples, which lead to the formation non-stoichiometric HAP with reduced Ca/P ratio. Ma et al. [49,50] studied the catalytic performance of N2O decomposition with HAP as the support. The results indicated that low Ca/P ratio would lead to the decrease of surface alkalinity, which was not conducive to the catalytic activity. Nevertheless, in the present work, the Co/nHAP catalyst with low Ca/P ratio shows higher activity, which indicates that Ca/P ratio may be not the main reason for the difference of catalytic activity. Moreover, H2-TPR results show that the existence of K, Na and Mg in nHAP can weaken the Co–O bond, which is also confirmed by XPS of Co2p. At the same time, XPS of Co2p show that Co3O4 on nHAP contains more amount of Co3+, which can provide more oxygen vacancies, and it is also proved by XPS of O1s. Finally, the results of O2-TPD demonstrate that the surface oxygen species attached to the oxygen vacancies are more abundant and easier to desorb, which can directly prove the fact of more oxygen vacancies and weakened CoO bonds. It is well known that the reaction mechanism of N2O decomposition on cobalt spinel-based catalyst is deemed to the following route: (I) N2O + Co–*–Co → Co–O–Co + N2 (II) 2Co–O–Co → O2 + 2 Co–*–Co (III) Co–O–Co + N2O→ O2 + N2 + Co–*–Co The apparent rate of the reaction over the cobalt based catalysts is controlled by the oxygen vacancy regeneration steps (II) and (III) [51,52]. It is obvious that the CoO bond strength as well as the amount of oxygen vacancy is significant to N2O decomposition. Based on our researching results, Co/nHAP exhibits higher catalytic activity than Co/HAP-Syn for N2O decomposition due to its weakened CoO bond and more amount of oxygen vacancies (*). At the same time, because of the weakening of CoO bond, its catalytic activity is less affected by the inhibition of O2, H2O, NO and CO2. 4 Conclusion By loading Co3O4 on nHAP and HAP-Syn, a superior active Co/nHAP catalyst for N2O decomposition has been obtained even under real reaction conditions (4.4 vol.% H2O, 3.0 vol.% O2, 0.015 vol.% NO or 4.0 vol.% CO2). In addition, the Co/nHAP catalyst was compared with the pure Co3O4 for the catalytic activity to elucidate the preponderance of nature HAP support in the existence of water vapor. The characterization results show that the average size of Co3O4 on the Co/nHAP is smaller than that on the Co/HAP-Syn. More importantly, the electronic properties of catalysts can be adjusted via alkali and alkaline-earth metal originated from nature bone, further increasing the quantity of oxygen vacancies and/or weakening the CoO bond, which are beneficial for N2O decomposition. It is believed that the facile synthesis, available large-scale production, environmental friendliness, low cost, non-toxic and excellent properties will make the nHAP support widely used in the practical application of N2O catalytic decomposition as well as other related fields. coredata.dc:description: Natural hydroxyapatite (nHAP) obtained from roasted pork bone was used as carrier of Co3O4 to prepare Co/nHAP catalyst for N2O catalytic decomposition. For the sake of contrast, the catalytic activity of Co3O4 supported on synthetic HAP (Co/HAP-Syn) and pure Co3O4 were also investigated. Activity tests indicate that the Co/nHAP could achieve higher catalytic activity than Co/HAP-Syn and pure Co3O4, even in impurity gases, as well as superior stability. The characterization results concluded that, compared with those on Co/HAP-Syn, the sizes of Co3O4 particles on Co/nHAP are smaller, which may contribute to enhance the quantity of active sites. More importantly, the existence of K, Na and Mg elements on the nHAP derived from bone can weaken the CoO bond and increase the amount of oxygen vacancies. All these factors could promote the catalytic activity as well as less inhibition affected by impurity gases. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on N2O catalytic decomposition making use of abandoned bones as effective support material, which can develop a sustainable and promising solution to the growing problem of environment.
coredata.dc:title: Co3O4 supported on bone-derived hydroxyapatite as potential catalysts for N2O catalytic decomposition
